fields.name: amount
fields.title: Amount
fields.description: Total inorganic nitrogen (N) fertilizer which was applied to this crop as a treatment factor. This does not include N in FYM or castor bean meal. Note at different periods of the experiment N was variously applied in autumn or spring and applied in a single application or split applications. Timings and amounts of N applied are indicated in the yield_data table in the fields spring1_n_kg/ha, spring1_n_date, spring2_n_kg/ha, spring2_n_date, etc.

fields.name: amount unit
fields.title: Amount unit
fields.description: Units in which the N was applied each year

fields.name: frequency
fields.title: Frequency
fields.description: The frequency at which the factor level treatment was applied

fields.name: treatment_form
fields.title: Treatment form
fields.description: The form of inorganic N fertilizer applied

fields.name: treatment_form_rdfType
fields.title: Treatment form rdfType
fields.description: A controlled vocabulary URI for the treatment factor level form

resources.title: N fertilizer treatment factor level descriptions
resources.description: Describes the different N (nitrogen) fertilizer  treatment factor levels used. N applied as calcium ammonium nitrate 1968-1985, as ammonium nitrate since 1986.

resources.title: P fertilizer treatment factor level descriptions
resources.description: Describes the P (phosphorus) fertilizer treatment factor levels used. Not applied to many plots since 2001 (and further plots since 2021) due to high levels of crop-available soil P.

resources.name: weed_data

fields.name: harvest_year
fields.title: Year in which crop harvested
fields.description: Year in which the crop was harvested. It will generally have been sown the previous year, eg the 1991 crop was sown in autumn 1990.  The harvest year is also the year in whiich the survey was conducted.

fields.name: strip
fields.title: strip
fields.description: Treatment strips extend the whole length of the field and receive the different fertilizer and manure treatments (1-22). There is no Strip 4. Strip 21 also known as 2.1, (or previously 2a or 2A),  Strip 22 also known as 2.2  (or previously 2b or 2B).

fields.name: section
fields.title: Section number 1968 onwards
fields.description: Since 1968 the treatment strips have been divided into 10 Sections (0-9) some in continuous wheat (0, 1, 6, 8 and 9) and some in rotation with non-wheat crops (2-5, 7, see previous crop). Since 1986 Section 0 has had straw incorporated. Section 6 was in a rotation of fallow>wheat>wheat 1968-1979, and reverted to continuous winter wheat in 1980 with no spring or summer fungicides. Herbicides have been used as required since 1964 on all of the experiment, except for Section 8 (old Section VA), which has never received herbicides. See plans for further details.

fields.name: plot
fields.title: plot
fields.description: Unique whole plot number, determined by Strip (1-22) and Section (0-9) number

fields.name: section_1926-67
fields.title: section 1926-1967
fields.description: Previous Section name, 1926-1967. Originally five Sections (I-V).  1926-1954, Section I divided into IA and IB in 1955, Section V divided in VA and VB in 1955.

fields.name: fertilizer_code
fields.title: fertilizer and manure treatment code
fields.description: Code describing the fertilizer or manure applied in that harvest year

fields.name: cropping
fields.title: cropping
fields.description: Cropping in that harvest year:  winter wheat, fallow (no crop, cultivated several times to remove weeds), spring wheat which was grown in some years when it was too wet to sow the usual winter wheat in the autumn. See crop_types_data for more information.

fields.name: year_of_wheat
fields.title: year of wheat
fields.description: Number of years since last non-wheat crop or fallow.

fields.name: previous_crop
fields.title: previous crop
fields.description: Crop grown in previous harvest year: winter wheat, spring wheat or fallow (no crop, cultivated to remove weeds).  See crop_types_data for more information.

fields.name: fym_factor_level
fields.title: FYM factor level
fields.description: Code for the farmyard manure (FYM) factor level applied in that harvest year

fields.name: fym_applied
fields.title: FYM applied
fields.description: Amount of farmyard manure (FYM) applied in that harvest year

fields.name: fym_date
fields.title: Date FYM applied
fields.description: Date farmyard manure (FYM) applied, usually in the autumn

fields.name: castor_meal_factor_level
fields.title: Castor meal factor level
fields.description: Code for the castor mean factor level applied in that harvest year. Before 1941 rape cake.

fields.name: castor_meal_n_applied
fields.title: Castor meal N applied
fields.description: Amount of N applied in the castor bean meal

fields.name: castor_meal_date
fields.title: Date castor meal applied
fields.description: Date castor bean meal applied, usually in the autumn

fields.name: n_factor_level
fields.title: N factor level
fields.description: Code for the inorganic nitrogen fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year

fields.name: n_timing
fields.title: Timing of fertilizer N
fields.description: When inorganic nitrogen fertilizer was applied: either all in autumn (autumn), all in spring (spring) or a combination of autumn and spring (autumn_&_spring). The spring N is either applied as a single application in mid-spring, or in two or three applications in early, mid or late spring (approximately March, April and May).

fields.name: autumn_n_kg/ha
fields.title: Fertilizer N applied in autumn
fields.description: Total inorganic nitrogen fertilizer treatments applied in the autumn to this crop. This does not include N applied in other treatments (FYM or castor meal).

fields.name: autumn_n_date
fields.title: Date fertilizer N applied in autumn
fields.description: Date inorganic fertilizer nitrogen applied in the autumn

fields.name: spring1_n_kg/ha
fields.title: First spring fertilizer N amount
fields.description: Amount of N in first application of inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in the spring to this crop. This does not include N in FYM or castor meal.

fields.name: spring1_n_date
fields.title: First spring fertilizer N date
fields.description: Date first application of inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in the spring.

fields.name: spring2_n_kg/ha
fields.title: Second spring fertilizer N amount
fields.description: Amount of N in second application of inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in the spring to this crop. This does not include N in FYM or castor meal.

fields.name: spring2_n_date
fields.title: Second spring fertilizer N date
fields.description: Date second application of inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in the spring.

fields.name: spring3_n_kg/ha
fields.title: Third spring fertilizer N amount
fields.description: Amount of N in third (final) application of inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in the spring to this crop. This does not include N in FYM or castor meal.

fields.name: spring3_n_date
fields.title: Third spring fertilizer N date
fields.description: Date third (final) application of inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in the spring.

fields.name: total_fertilizer_n_amount
fields.title: Total inorganic nitrogen fertilizer N amount
fields.description: Total inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in autumn and spring to this crop. This does not include N in FYM or castor meal.

fields.name: p_factor_level
fields.title: P factor level
fields.description: Code for the phosphorous (P) fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year

fields.name: p_amount
fields.title: P amount
fields.description: Total amount of inorganic P fertilizer applied in that harvest year. This does not include P in FYM or castor bean meal.

fields.name: p_date
fields.title: P fertilizer application date
fields.description: Date inorganic P fertilizer applied in that harvest year.

fields.name: k_factor_level
fields.title: K factor level
fields.description: Code for the potassium (K) fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year

fields.name: k_amount
fields.title: K amount
fields.description: Total amount of inorganic K fertilizer applied in that harvest year. This does not include K in FYM or castor bean meal.

fields.name: k_date
fields.title: K fertilizer application date
fields.description: Date inorganic K fertilizer applied in that harvest year.

fields.name: na_factor_level
fields.title: Na factor level
fields.description: Code for the sodium (Na) fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year

fields.name: na_amount
fields.title: Na amount
fields.description: Total amount of inorganic Na fertilizer applied in that harvest year. This does not include Na in FYM or castor bean meal.

fields.name: na_date
fields.title: Na fertilizer application date
fields.description: Date inorganic Na fertilizer applied in that harvest year.

fields.name: mg_factor_level
fields.title: Mg factor level
fields.description: Code for the magnesium (Mg) fertilizer factor level applied in that harvest year

fields.name: mg_amount
fields.title: Mg amount
fields.description: Total amount of inorganic Mg fertilizer applied in that harvest year. This does not include Mg in FYM or castor bean meal.

fields.name: mg_date
fields.title: Mg fertilizer application date
fields.description: Date inorganic Mg fertilizer applied in that harvest year.

fields.name: survey_date
fields.title: Date weed survey conducted
fields.description: Date weed survey was conducted in the Broadbalkfield experiment

fields.title: Frequency of Aethusa cynapium

fields.title: Sowing date
fields.description: Date the crop was sown, generally in the autumn in the year before harvest

fields.title: Harvest date
fields.description: Date the crop was harvested

fields.title: Cultivar
fields.description: Wheat cultivar or variety

fields.name: total_grain
fields.title: total wheat grain yield
fields.description: Harvested wheat grain yield at 85% dry matter.  This includes weed seeds.

fields.name: cleaned_grain
fields.title: cleaned wheat grain yield
fields.description: Harvested wheat grain yield at 85% dry matter minus weed seeds which have been cleaned from the samples.

fields.name: straw
fields.title: wheat straw yield
fields.description: Harvested wheat straw yield at 85% dry matter. Straw does not include stubble.

fields.title: percentage of total yield that is weed seed
fields.description: Percentage of harvested  yield that is weed seeds.

fields.title: weight of total yield that is weed seed
fields.description: Weight of harvested  yield that is weed seeds.

fields.name: notes_id
fields.title: Note
fields.description: Whether notes are applied or not

resources.title: weed data
resources.description: The main data table containing annual frequencies of each weed species present in each plot (strip) of section 8 (no herbicides  ever applied, continuous wheat), 1991-2021. It also includes wheat grain yields (with 'Total'  and without weed seeds 'Cleaned') and straw yield data, plus details of all fertilizer and manure treatments. Also other agronomic information, including sowing and harvest dates, amount, type and date of application of treatments, and wheat cultivars. The Broadbalk Wheat Experiment was started in autumn 1843 to investigate the effects of fertilizers containing N, P, K, Na and Mg in various combinations, and organic manure, on the yield of winter wheat grown continuously. The treatment STRIPS (3-22) extend the whole length of the field; each strip tests a different fertilizer or manure treatment. In 1926 the strips were divided into five SECTIONS (I-V), bare fallowed in sequence to control weeds. There were further divisions in 1955 making seven Sections (IA-VB). In 1968 the strips were divided into 10 SECTIONS (0-9) and Strip 1 (Sections 2-7 only) was added.  Each PLOT is a unique strip\section combination. Sections 0, 1, 6 and 9 remained in continuous winter wheat but are not included in this dataset as they receive herbicides.  Section 8 has never received herbicides; it is bare fallowed with frequent cultivation every 5-8 years to control weeds. See notes and section names.pdf for full details of Broadbalk Experiment layout.

fields.name: latin_name
fields.title: latin_name
fields.description: Latin botanical name of crop type

fields.name: common_name
fields.title: common_name
fields.description: English name of crop type

fields.name: ncbitaxon_uri
fields.title: ncbitaxon_uri
fields.description: A controlled vocabulary URI for the weed species

name: broadbalk-weed-survey-data-1991-2021
title: Broadbalk Weed Survey Data 1991-2021
description:
### Abstract
This dataset consists of the relative annual frequencies of all non-crop plant species ('weeds') recorded in all eighteen plots of section 8 of the Broadbalk wheat experiment, 1991-2021. Section 8 has not received any herbicides in its history - in contrast to the other sections of Broadbalk which have received herbicides since 1964. Broadbalk section 8 is one of the few arable sites in the country where herbicides have never been applied. Consequently it is populated by a rich diversity of arable species, some very rare elsewhere in England. Broadbalk continues to act as a valuable resource for weed investigations 180 years after it was established, for example Moss _et al._ (2004).

There have been various surveys of weeds on Broadbalk wheat experiment since its conception in 1843, but not a consistent methodology in these. The first plot-by-plot surveys of weed species were done in 1869 recording the presence of species. The first phase of annual surveys was between 1933-1979 prior to the current layout of sections. The current weed survey was started on section 8 in 1991 and has continued annually ever since - although not on years when that section is in fallow: 1994, 2001, 2008, 2015, 2016 and 2022. Section 8 (called section VA 1958-1967) was created in 1968 when the experiment was divided into its present layout (Broadbalk plan today).  

The current assessment method records the presence of individual weed species in 25 random quadrats (0.1m<sup>2</sup>) per plot. The plots receive differing types and rates of fertilizer treatments and the weed species reflect these. Each year all 18 plots are surveyed meaning 450 quadrats are assessed per year, usually in June. Frequencies refer to the total number of quadrats in which a weed is recorded, the maximum being 25 per plot and 450 across all plots in the section. This method is more appropriate for detecting long-term trends in weed frequencies and population differences between plots than the earlier surveys and provides a comprehensive set of 20 years of data for weed studies.  

There have been 60 different species identified over the 30-year duration of this current survey, but many of these only occur sporadically and around 30 of these are currently recorded annually. This site also provides an invaluable reserve for seven nationally rare or uncommon species including corn cleavers (_Galium tricornutum_), corn buttercup (_Ranunculus arvensis_), shepherds needle (_Scandix pecten-veneris_) and prickly poppy (_Papaver argemone_). This is now the only location in the UK where corn cleavers is known to occur naturally. 

This valuable resource, and associated data, allows the study of long-term interactions between plant species, an opportunity to test current controversies in population and community ecology such as equilibrium theories which require data on resource requirements and loss rates. The long time series enables the detection of cycles in the abundance of individual species; to determine to stability of weed communities; it  enables various weed investigations including weed population ecology; studies on the effects of fallowing on the weed seed bank; seed dormancy and persistence; agroecology and population dynamics of individual weed species. Recently, molecular approaches have been used to study the genetic diversity of weeds found on Section 8, this rare herbicide-free arable plot. On plots where inorganic nitrogen fertiliser has been applied, potential yield losses from weeds have consistently increased since 1969. This was explained by a warming climate, measured as air temperature averaged over the growing season for the weeds, and a shift towards shorter crop cultivars (Storkey et al 2021). Weeds on Broadbalk may genetically more competitive now due to selection for more competitive individuals


This dataset also provides the yields of the plots both with and without the weight of the weed seeds. The percentage of weed seeds in the total grain varies between greatly, between 1-71.8% of the total grain yield. The year 2012 was a particularly high weed year followed by 2007 and 2013.  

**Herbicide Resistance Studies:** This section 8 of Broadbalk is an important source of susceptible seed of the weed _Alopecurus myosuroides_, blackgrass. It provides an excellent standard susceptible strain for use in herbicide-resistance assays, as having never received herbicides the grass-weed has never evolved herbicide resistance. See "Herbicide resistance in _Alopecurus myosuroides_: The value of routine testing of seed samples submitted by farmers since 1985", Cook et al. Weed Research (2023).
### Methods
The assessment method records the presence of individual weed species in 25 random quadrats (0.1m2) per plot. Each year all 18 plots were surveyed meaning 450 quadrats are assessed per year, usually in June. Frequencies refer to the total number of quadrats in which the species is recorded, the maximum being 25 per plot and 450 across all plots in the section.  

The weed survey generally takes place in June, precise dates are indicated in the dataset.

The yield correction for weed seed contamination, from 1992: Two samples (1kg each) were taken from the grain samples harvested from each plot. These samples were cleaned with a Petcus seed cleaner fitted with a 3.3mm round hole top sieve and a 2.0mm slot type bottom sieve. The sample was tipped directly onto the top sieve, not via the air stream separator. Four fractions were collected and weighed: 
a. >3.5mm retained on top sieve, mainly threshed heads,
b. <2.0mm passed through bottom sieve, mainly weed seeds (black-grass, black-medick, shepherds needle) and some small grains,
c. retained on bottom sieve, first fraction from rotary separator, mainly wheat grain with a small amount of weed seed contamination (mainly vetch),
d. retained on bottom sieve, second fraction from rotary separator, a variable mixture of wheat and vetch.
Sample d was sub-sampled to determine grain content. Two sub-samples (each ~5g) were taken, the grain & weed seeds separated manually, and the two fractions weighed. This determined the d grain is each sub-sample and the mean of the two samples calculated. This value was used to calculate the weight of cleaned grain in the entire d fraction. Cleaned grain weight was then calculated from fraction c plus grain weight of fraction d for each of the two samples collected per plot. Total cleaned weight was then expressed as a % of the total sample weight, and the mean of these two samples calculated. Thus a single % correction factor was derived. The combine yields (t/ha corrected to 15%moisture content / 85% dry matter) were then adjusted using this correction factor to derive a clean 'weed free' grain yield (t/ha) for each plot.
### Technical Info
No weeds present in fallow years, due to frequent cultivation which kills emerging weed plants.  

Broadbalk Section 8   Yield of grain from combine, yield of clean grain, 1992-2022: Clean grain excludes grain <2mm and >3.5mm. This excludes the weed seeds. 

 Section 8 is fallowed frequently to control weeds (i.e no crop is grown).
### Other
Note. 2022 was a Fallow year.
Data for 2023 will be available in the next version.  

Note from 2014 yield book: Clean grain yields reported for 2012 and 2013 are about 5% less than those reported in the 2013 yield book because they exclude small (<2mm) grains. In future, clean grain yields for Section 8 will be reported for the 2-3.5mm grain size fraction, excluding grain <2mm, as was the practice prior to 2012.
### Provenance
This weed survey was initiated by Stephen Moss in 1991. 

The data has been recorded & provided by staff of the Weed Ecology Group, Rothamsted Research; led by Richard Hull, Stephen Moss, Jon Storkey who apply all appropriate quality assurance checks.
### Quality
This data is recorded & provided by staff of the Weed Ecology Group, Rothamsted Research; led by Richard Hull, Stephen Moss, Jon Storkey who apply all appropriate quality assurance checks.
